ticket.title: a :partial option in assert_template
ticket.original-body:
In one app I work on I have to spend a fair amount of test code ensuring that partials are rendered (or not) depending on user permissions and what data exists and so on and so forth. Until now I've just been writing helpers named `tag_list_rendered` and `bookmark_toggle_rendered` and such, all of which liberally use `assert_select` to divine if the output I want is there.
Right below all those helpers were `assert_template`s, and I realized just how more readable `assert_template :partial => 'shared/_bookmark_toggle'` would be than `assert bookmark_toggle_rendered`. So with this patch you can now do:
`assert_template 'index'` and `assert_template nil` like you can now. `assert_template :partial => '_name'` to assert if it was rendered `assert_template :partial => '_name', :count => 14` to assert it was rendered a specific number of times `assert_template :partial => '_name', :count => 0` to assert that given partial was not rendered `assert_template :partial => false` to assert that no partials were rendered.
ticket.latest-body:
In one app I work on I have to spend a fair amount of test code ensuring that partials are rendered (or not) depending on user permissions and what data exists and so on and so forth. Until now I've just been writing helpers named `tag_list_rendered` and `bookmark_toggle_rendered` and such, all of which liberally use `assert_select` to divine if the output I want is there.
Right below all those helpers were `assert_template`s, and I realized just how more readable `assert_template :partial => 'shared/_bookmark_toggle'` would be than `assert bookmark_toggle_rendered`. So with this patch you can now do:
`assert_template 'index'` and `assert_template nil` like you can now. `assert_template :partial => '_name'` to assert if it was rendered `assert_template :partial => '_name', :count => 14` to assert it was rendered a specific number of times `assert_template :partial => '_name', :count => 0` to assert that given partial was not rendered `assert_template :partial => false` to assert that no partials were rendered.
ticket.original-body-html:
In one app I work on I have to spend a fair amount of test code ensuring that partials are rendered (or not) depending on user permissions and what data exists and so on and so forth. Until now I've just been writing helpers named tag_list_rendered and bookmark_toggle_rendered and such, all of which liberally use assert_select to divine if the output I want is there.

Right below all those helpers were assert_templates, and I realized just how more readable assert_template :partial => 'shared/_bookmark_toggle' would be than assert bookmark_toggle_rendered. So with this patch you can now do:

assert_template 'index' and assert_template nil like you can now. assert_template :partial => '_name' to assert if it was rendered assert_template :partial => '_name', :count => 14 to assert it was rendered a specific number of times assert_template :partial => '_name', :count => 0 to assert that given partial was not rendered assert_template :partial => false to assert that no partials were rendered.

version.body:
In one app I work on I have to spend a fair amount of test code ensuring that partials are rendered (or not) depending on user permissions and what data exists and so on and so forth. Until now I've just been writing helpers named `tag_list_rendered` and `bookmark_toggle_rendered` and such, all of which liberally use `assert_select` to divine if the output I want is there.
Right below all those helpers were `assert_template`s, and I realized just how more readable `assert_template :partial => 'shared/_bookmark_toggle'` would be than `assert bookmark_toggle_rendered`. So with this patch you can now do:
`assert_template 'index'` and `assert_template nil` like you can now.
`assert_template :partial => '_name'` to assert if it was rendered
`assert_template :partial => '_name', :count => 14` to assert it was rendered a specific number of times
`assert_template :partial => '_name', :count => 0` to assert that given partial was not rendered
`assert_template :partial => false` to assert that no partials were rendered.
version.body-html:
In one app I work on I have to spend a fair amount of test code ensuring that partials are rendered (or not) depending on user permissions and what data exists and so on and so forth. Until now I've just been writing helpers named tag_list_rendered and bookmark_toggle_rendered and such, all of which liberally use assert_select to divine if the output I want is there.

Right below all those helpers were assert_templates, and I realized just how more readable assert_template :partial => 'shared/_bookmark_toggle' would be than assert bookmark_toggle_rendered. So with this patch you can now do:

assert_template 'index' and assert_template nil like you can now.

assert_template :partial => '_name' to assert if it was rendered

assert_template :partial => '_name', :count => 14 to assert it was rendered a specific number of times

assert_template :partial => '_name', :count => 0 to assert that given partial was not rendered

assert_template :partial => false to assert that no partials were rendered.
version.title: a :partial option in assert_template

version.body: Apologies - this is the diff I meant to attach

version.title: a :partial option in assert_template

version.body:
I'm down for adding support for this, but I have a few concerns.
I'm mainly worried about performance. Tracking these counts hurts a little bit. And this data is only going to be used in tests. So your production env is still doing all this work and throwing it away.
My ideal solution would be to monkey patch the render method when we start a testing env so it wouldn't affect production performance at all.
Also, I really hate @_first_render, if you can knock that out too, that would be awesome.
version.body-html:
I'm down for adding support for this, but I have a few concerns.

I'm mainly worried about performance. Tracking these counts hurts a little bit. And this data is only going to be used in tests. So your production env is still doing all this work and throwing it away.

My ideal solution would be to monkey patch the render method when we start a testing env so it wouldn't affect production performance at all.

Also, I really hate @_first_render, if you can knock that out too, that would be awesome.
version.title: a :partial option in assert_template

version.body: Alrighty, it now patches the tracking stuff in when actionview's test setup stuff is loaded.
version.body-html: Alrighty, it now patches the tracking stuff in when actionview's test setup stuff is loaded.
version.title: a :partial option in assert_template
